Algebraic Varieties In FinInG we provide some basic functionality for algebraic varieties defined over finite fields. The algebraic varieties in FinInG are defined by a list of multivariate polynomials over a finite field, and an ambient geometry. This ambient geometry is either a projective space, and then the algebraic variety is called a projective variety, or an affine geometry, and then the algebraic variety is called an affine variety. In this chapter we give a brief overview of the features of FinInG concerning these two types of algebraic varieties.
Algebraic Varieties An algebraic variety in FinInG is an algebraic variety in a projective space or affine space, defined by a list of polynomials over a finite field.
an algebraic variety
The argument space is an affine or projective space over a finite field F, the argument pring is a multivariate polynomial ring defined over (a subfield of) F, and pollist is a list of polynomials in pring. If the space is a projective space, then pollist needs to be a list of homogeneous polynomials. In FinInG there are two types of projective varieties: projective varieties and affine varieties. The following operations apply to both types.

Affine Varieties An affine variety in FinInG is an algebraic variety in an affine space defined by a list of polynomials over a finite field.

The argument ag is an affine space over a finite field F, the argument pring is a multivariate polynomial ring defined over (a subfield of) F, and pollist is a list of polynomials in pring.

Grassmann Varieties A Grassmann variety in FinInG is a projective algebraic variety in a projective space over a finite field. The set of points that lie on this variety is the image of the Grassmann map.
Quadrics and Hermitian varieties Quadrics and Hermitian varieties are objects by default considered as a classical polar space. But they belong also to the category IsProjectiveVariety (but not to the Representation IsProjectiveVarietyRep). This implies that in principle, operations applicable to objects in IsProjectiveVariety are applicable to quadrics and Hermitian varieties too. Furthermore, we provide a method for PolarSpace taking as an argument a projective algebraic variety. The appropriate form is constructed, when possible of course, using the Forms functions QuadraticFormByPolynomial and HermitianFormByPolynomial.
the argument var is a projective algebraic variety. When its list of definining polynomial contains exactaly one polynomial, depending on its degree, the operation QuadraticFormByPolynomial or HermitianFormByPolynomial is used to compute a quadratic form or a hermitian form. These operations check whether this is possible, and produce an error message if not. If the conversion is possible, then the appropriate polar space is returned.
